newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish cabinet to discuss banking draft next week.
newsitem.headline: Polish cabinet to discuss banking draft next week.

text.p: The Polish government is likely to discuss next week a new, more liberal banking law which would introduce European Union standards to the sector, Karol Szwarc, a deputy finance minister, said on Monday.

He told Reuters in an interview that under the draft the upper limit of a bank's credit exposure to a single company would be raised to 25 percent of the bank's own assets from the current 10 percent.
"The draft...likely to be discussed by the government next week... introduces changes adjusting Polish law to European Union standards, and opens up the market," said Szwarc.

He added the draft would probably envisage more stringent rules on the acquisition of shares in banks by introducing a requirement for a central bank permission on a purchase of stock giving more than five percent of votes.
The National Bank of Poland's permission is now required to execute more than 10 percent of votes.
Szwarc added that under the draft the central bank's Banking Supervision department would be subordinated to a Banking Supervision Committee.

The General Banking Supervision Inspectorate (GINB), now a central bank agency which executes all controlling and monitoring functions over the banking sector, would carry on as an executive arm of the supervision committee.

The committee would be chaired by the NBP's president and would include representatives of the NBP, the finance ministry, the Presidential Chancellery, the Securities Commission and the Banking Guarantee Fund.

Szwarc said the arrangement was a result of a compromise between the government, which wanted to carve out banking supervision from the central bank to form an independent agency and the NBP which to keep supervision within its structure.
